questions.text: Match the following?
questions.solution:
• Type 1 tympanoplastyinvolves placing a graft on the malleus to repair a perforation in the tympanic membrane. The malleus is the largest bone in the ossicular chain, and it is located on the medial side of the tympanic membrane. The graft is placed on the malleus to provide a framework for the tympanic membrane to heal over.
  • Type 2 tympanoplastyinvolves placing a graft on the incus to repair a perforation in the tympanic membrane and to reconstruct the ossicular chain. The incus is the second largest bone in the ossicular chain, and it is located between the malleus and the stapes. The graft is placed on the incus to provide a framework for the tympanic membrane to heal over, and to also help to transmit sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the stapes.
  • Type 3 tympanoplastyinvolves placing a graft on the head of the stapes to repair a perforation in the tympanic membrane and to reconstruct the entire ossicular chain. The stapes is the smallest bone in the ossicular chain, and it is located on the medial side of the middle ear. The graft is placed on the head of the stapes to provide a framework for the tympanic membrane to heal over, and to also help to transmit sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear.
  • Type 4 tympanoplastyis a type of tympanoplasty that is performed to treat cholesteatoma. Cholesteatoma is a benign growth of skin cells that can grow in the middle ear. Type 4 tympanoplasty involves removing the cholesteatoma and reconstructing the tympanic membrane and ossicular chain.

questions.text: All of the following are smell perception tests except?
questions.solution:
The Arnold stick test is a test for olfaction that involves the use of a cotton swab dipped in a chemical called amyl acetate. The swab is then waved in front of the patient's nose, and the patient is asked to identify the smell. This test is not a reliable measure of smell perception because the smell of amyl acetate is very strong and can be easily detected even by people with impaired smell.

All of the options except Arnold stick test are used to measure smell perception. Arnold stick test is not a reliable measure of smell perception because the smell of amyl acetate is very strong and can be easily detected even by people with impaired smell.

A. Smell diskettes

Smell diskettes are small, disposable disks that contain a variety of different odors. The patient is asked to smell the diskettes and identify the odors. This test is a measure of the patient's ability to smell.

B. UP-SIT

UP-SIT stands for Upper Airway Resistance Sensitivity Index Test. This test is used to assess the resistance of the upper airway to airflow. The test is performed by measuring the pressure drop across the upper airway when the patient breathes in and out.

C. CC-SIT

CC-SIT stands for Conductance Change Sensitivity Index Test. This test is also used to assess the resistance of the upper airway to airflow. The test is performed by measuring the change in conductance of the upper airway when the patient breathes in and out.

questions.text:
If OAE is absent in a patient, which other screening test can be done?
A. BERA
B. Tympanometry
C. Audiometry
D. Speech Audiometry
questions.solution:
OAE (Otoacoustic Emissions) is a test that measures sound emissions produced by the cochlea in response to acoustic stimuli. If OAE is absent, it may indicate a problem in the cochlea's function. To further assess the patient's hearing, the following tests can be done:

B. Tympanometry: Tympanometry is a test that measures the compliance of the middle ear and the mobility of the eardrum (tympanic membrane). It helps detect conditions such as middle ear effusion (fluid), tympanic membrane perforation, or other disorders affecting the middle ear.

D. Speech Audiometry: Speech audiometry evaluates the patient's ability to hear and understand speech at different volumes. It is used to determine the patient's hearing threshold for speech and assess their ability to discriminate speech sounds.

A. BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry): It is suitable for assessing cochlear function or detecting OAE since it measures auditory brainstem responses, mainly focusing on the function of the auditory nerve and brainstem pathways.

C. Audiometry: It is not a suitable alternative for OAE because audiometry assesses hearing sensitivity at different frequencies but does not directly measure the cochlear emissions detected by OAE.

questions.text: The marked structure opens into which of the following spaces ?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image points to the sphenoid sinus. The sphenoethmoidal recess is a small, anatomical space located in the upper part of the nasal cavity where the sphenoid sinus and the ethmoid sinus meet. It is an important region in the nasal cavity and plays a role in the drainage and ventilation of these paranasal sinuses.

  • Option B. Superior Meatus: The superior meatus is a space in the nasal cavity located below the superior nasal concha. The sphenoid sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is adjacent to the superior meatus.
  • Option C. Middle Meatus: The middle meatus is another space in the nasal cavity located below the middle nasal concha. It is a critical area for the drainage of several paranasal sinuses, including the anterior ethmoidal sinus, frontal sinus, and maxillary sinus. The sphenoid sinus does not open directly into the middle meatus.
  • Option D. Inferior Meatus: The inferior meatus is a space in the nasal cavity located below the inferior nasal concha. It serves as the opening for the nasolacrimal duct, which drains tears from the eyes to the nasal cavity. The sphenoid sinus does not open directly into the inferior meatus.

questions.text: A patient with nasal deformity comes to OPD. O/E there is septal perforation with pale granuloma and biopsy showed granuloma multinucleated giant cells, and caseous necrosis. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of septal perforation with pale granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and caseous necrosis suggests a diagnosis of Tuberculosis.

Other options explanations:

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum, and it can lead to destructive lesions, including septal perforation, in the nose.

Wegener's granulomatosis: This is a systemic autoimmune disease that can affect the nose, but it does not typically cause granuloma multinucleated giant cells or caseous necrosis.

NK lymphoma - T cell/Non-healing lymphoma: This is a type of cancer that can affect the nose, but it does not typically cause granuloma multinucleated giant cells or caseous necrosis.

questions.text: Foreign body entry in the laryngeal inlet, prevented by cough reflex. Reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured/damaged?
questions.solution:
Internal laryngeal nerve (ILN): Above the vocal cords, The sensory supply of the larynx is supplied by the internal laryngeal nerve- a branch of superior laryngeal nerve. So as mentioned in the question when a foreign body enters in the laryngeal inlet coughing reflex occurs as a preventive measure. In cases of alcohol it affects the sensitivity of the laryngeal inlet as the ILN may be affected, leading to a sluggish reflex.

Option A: ELN (External laryngeal nerve): innervate the cricothyroid muscle and is not involved in the cough reflex.

Option C: RLN (Recurrent Laryngeal nerve): is responsible for the innervation of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx and the sensory innervation to the larynx below the vocal cords. It does not produce a cough reflex.

Option D: Glossopharyngeal nerve: is responsible for the sensory innervation to the oropharynx and the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue but is not involved in the cough reflex.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Internal laryngeal nerve which is a branch of superior laryngeal nerve gives sensory supply to pyriform fossa and supraglottis.

choices.text: Left rinne's negative, weber lateralized to right ear
Left rinne's positive, weber lateralized to right ear
Left rinne's positive, weber lateralized to left ear
Left rinne's Negative, weber lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A Patient is not able to hear properly from the left ear given an audiogram. What will be finding of Rinne and weber test and which ear is asked?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is experiencing hearing loss in the left ear. The Rinne and Weber tests are used to assess the patient's hearing and lateralization of sound perception.

  • Right Rinne's positive: When the tuning fork is placed on the mastoid bone (bone conduction) and then moved to the front of the ear (air conduction), the patient can hear the sound better through air conduction (front of the ear) than bone conduction (mastoid bone) in the right ear.
  • Weber lateralized to the right ear: When the tuning fork is placed on the center of the forehead, the patient perceives the sound as being louder or localized to the right ear.
  • This is a case of left side Sensorineural hearing loss. Thus Left Rinne's test positive and weber lateralized to the right ear is the correct option.

choices.text: Loss of taste sensation on anterior ⅔ of tongue
Loss of sensation on posterior ⅓ of tongue
Loss of sensory from anterior ⅔rd tongue
Loss of taste sensation & sensory from anterior ⅔rd of tongue

questions.text: What will happen if the jugular foramen gets damaged?
questions.solution:
The jugular foramen is a large opening in the skull through which several important structures pass, including cranial nerves IX (glossopharyngeal), X (vagus), and XI (accessory). Damage to the jugular foramen can affect the functions of these cranial nerves.

Option A: Loss of taste sensation on the anterior ⅔ of the tongue, is not affected because the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) supplies taste sensation to the posterior ⅓ of the tongue.

Option C: Loss of sensory from the anterior ⅔rd of the tongue, is not affected because the anterior ⅔ of the tongue is supplied by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (CN VII).

Option D: Loss of taste sensation & sensory from the anterior ⅔rd of the tongue, is incorrect as explained above.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Anterior 2/3rd of tongue

General sensation is by lingual nerve while taste sensation is by chorda tympani.

  • Posterior 1/3rd of tongue

Both general and taste sensation is by glossopharyngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 6 years old school going child presented with hearing loss. O/E there was a high arched palate with crowding of upper teeth. Tympanometry was done and the image of the tympanogram is shown. Which of the following surgeries may be required in this patient?
questions.solution:
The tympanogram image shown suggests a type B tympanogram, which indicates middle ear effusion (fluid) and reduced mobility of the tympanic membrane. In a 6-year-old child with hearing loss, middle ear effusion can be a common cause.

Grommet insertion (tympanostomy tube insertion) involves placing a tiny tube through the tympanic membrane to drain the middle ear fluid and equalize pressure. Adenoidectomy may also be performed as adenoid hypertrophy can contribute to Eustachian tube dysfunction and middle ear effusion.

Option A: Myringotomy with grommet insertion, refers to a similar procedure without adenoidectomy.

Option B: Tympanoplasty, is not appropriate for a child with middle ear effusion and a type B tympanogram.

Option D: Adenoidectomy alone, may not address the middle ear effusion if it is present.

questions.text: Patient presents with nasal obstruction. History of failed conservative management, H/O FESS with OT notes saying uncinectomy, maxillary ostium dilated. On DNE this time- oedema present in maxillary sinus lining with accessory ostium. What will be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient has a history of failed conservative management, and the findings on diagnostic nasal endoscopy (DNE) show edema in the maxillary sinus lining with an accessory ostium. Considering the previous FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery) and the presence of edema and obstruction in the sinuses, the next step in management would be re-surgery or revision surgery.

Option A, Steroids, may be used in conservative management, but since it has already failed, it would not be the next step.

Option C, Biological therapy, is not indicated in the given scenario.

Option D, Culture-directed antibiotics + nasal decongestant, may be part of the conservative management, but considering the history of failed conservative management and the findings on DNE, re-surgery is more appropriate.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance?
questions.solution:
Nasal mucociliary clearance refers to the process by which mucus and debris are cleared from the nasal passages through the action of cilia on the nasal epithelium. Several tests can be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance, but electron microscopy is not one of them.

These are valid methods to assess nasal mucociliary clearance:

A. Saccharine Test: This is a simple test in which a small amount of saccharine is placed in the nostril, and the time it takes for the patient to perceive a sweet taste in the mouth is measured. The movement of saccharine through the nasal passages indicates mucociliary clearance.

C. Charcoal powder method: In this test, charcoal particles are insufflated into the nasal cavity, and the time it takes for the patient to expectorate the particles is measured. The clearance of charcoal particles indicates mucociliary clearance.

D. Scintigraphy: Radioactive particles are used in this test to assess the movement of mucus through the nasal passages and the clearance of radioactive particles indicates mucociliary clearance.

Electron microscopy is not a method used for assessing nasal mucociliary clearance. Instead, it is a microscopic technique used to study the ultrastructure of cilia and mucociliary function in certain research settings.
